positive.review:
[h2] [b] Embrace the cringey dialogue dumps and you'll have a great time with Persona 4, as it has its charm and is, all in all, a fun and relaxing game to experience with a controller. [/b] [/h2]

[b] I assume most of the players would like to get the golden true ending with their first playthrough, which is not too complicated to achieve but can be easy to miss out on. You don't have to do everything perfectly, but do make sure you befriend the character named [spoiler] Marie and complete all her social links since she becomes an important character later on. [/spoiler] Also, have multiple save files in case you do something you shouldn't have once you reach December/Wintertime. From there, when you're close to the end of the game, and you'll know when you are, look up which choices you should pick in the final dialogues and you should be GOLDEN.

I hid the name with a spoiler tag, supposing you don‚Äôt want to know even that, but it‚Äôs not actually a spoiler.
Merely trying to be helpful. [/b]

[h3] Story, Characters & Writing: [/h3]

It's a Japanese school life story with extra mystery added to keep your mind intrigued, and it does a pretty good job at that. Yes, it's not all that serious, but it has some mature moments here and there from time to time.
I have no complaints whatsoever; it's enjoyable for me.
Every character is likable, romance is not forced upon you, but you have many choices for that as well, and it's genuinely sweet.

The game has lots of comedic value.
Even the side characters have their little stories, and some of them you can romance too. I wouldn‚Äôt romance them myself because I prefer the main cast to have more plot and time spent with them.

You have the opportunity to replay the game in different ways since there are distinct paths the narrative can take depending on your decisions.
Be open-minded to the fact that not everything needs to be written in a specific way. Variety of experiences can be worthwhile, and because it‚Äôs dissimilar to other forms of writing, it can be remarkable in its own way.

[h3] Gameplay: [/h3]

It's a JRPG with daily tasks that you perform to build relationship points or develop personal skills such as knowledge, expression, and diligence, which in turn benefit those relationships by unlocking certain dialogue options. You go to school, study, work, and complete side quests within the world you inhabit day to day.

The social links you develop are a crucial upgrade, as your performance in combat heavily depends on these relationships. They determine how well you do and how effectively you can get better Personas through fusions.

Obviously, there are optimal ways to play the game with specific builds, but there is also a lot of variety, including many elements or physical damage, passives, single-target skills, and AoE damage options. With different party members to choose from, experiment freely and enjoy yourself.

The side quests in the world are, in all honesty, not my favorite because most of them are fetch quests, but they do add something to occupy your in-game days and help you feel more connected to the city.

The game can be a little grindy if you fight everything to maximize money, EXP, and resources. That is the only aspect that might reasonably feel tedious.

Additionally, the soundtrack is cheerful and pleasant, completing the environment.

If this style is your thing and you can accept it for what it is, I believe it can be a memorable and entertaining teenage adventure.
If just seeing a character‚Äôs picture, hearing a song from the game, or listening to a voice actor can awaken a flood of memories, the game succeeds brilliantly as an art form
I believe Persona 4 Golden does that.

9/10.

After getting all achievements (thanks to a guide) I can finally say that P4G is my favourite Persona game and, probably, the best one despite P5R having the best gameplay mechanics and QOL quirks.

Persona 4 has the best characters, the best script, a very good OST, good dub both in japanese and english (P4G is very good, unlike P4). Not only the characters were written as credible teenagers but they're also very believable and likable. Every social link story, every sidequest, every piece of humor... is incredibly fun and relatable. By far, the most interesting, fun and well written cast of Persona protagonists. By far.

The negative sides are, of course P4G being an outdated port, having outdated dungeon mechanics and feeling like an "old game" whereas many other JRPG have more dynamic and fun gameplay loops and mechanics... The sidequests and NPCs fetch quests are very obscure, the dungeon grind and leveling is not "friendly" and too many things are "hidden" or definitively not on plain sight for the player to do or enjoy... something that never happens on most modern Atlus games, for instance.

The 100% is very hard, you definitively need a guide. There are so many things that aren't explained, hidden between odd dialogue choices, the activities (for instance, reading all the books)... the whole "Golden Ending" being hidden behind the most antinatural and vague dialogue choice option is still baffling. Satisfying once you advance NG+ but... damn, so hard to complete everything.

Totally recommended game, very fun and full of charm and appeal.

This is a jrpg creature collector about a serial killer in a small Japanese town. You play as a member of a group of high school friends who have figured out that the killer broadcasts their victims on tv the night before they are murdered. The game play loop is basically spending your day at school or out with friends doing different activities building relationships. It's really a worker placement type mechanic. There are a bunch of things to do in a day with various effects, but you can only choose a couple each day. That's when most of the story is told, in a visual novel style with occasional animated cutscenes. The relationships build power and abilities for you and your party before going into the dungeons, which is the second part of the loop, going into the tv world areas to try and save the next victim before they die. There you collect your creatures called personas that you use to fight the monsters called shadows. 

I enjoyed the main story and all the little stories that you learn building the relationships, there is a lot of humour and silly antics between the kids. The combat is fun, pretty simple. You can go down a rabbit hole trying to collect and combine your personas into more powerful ones. The dungeons can be a bit grindy. Some take several hours to complete, and sometimes you have to do them more than once to get strong enough for the next encounters. I liked the game and would play others in the series. I'd recommend playing with Japanese voice acting.

First of all - welcome to the town of Inaba, my second home away from home! To someone living in a small-to-midsized town it feels very familiar, and even the title of the first track you'll hear (after the opening that is) - Corner of Memories - sums up perfectly just how special this rural Japanese town will become to anyone who gets past the rather dragged out introductory sequence and spends the next 70+ hours with it.

If Persona 3 was a neatly crafted monument to living life to it's full extent, then Persona 4, notably lacking existential dread for the most part, somehow amps that up to the power of ten and beyond. Though the gameplay may be a bit lacking in some departments, compared to Persona 5 and everything that came after it, the game makes up for it sevenfold in every other area and having fleshed out the Social Link mechanic introduced in 3, certainly does it's best to make you want to spend as much time as possible with those few that will no doubt become your virtual best friends by the time the game is over. You've got everything - from your overworked detective uncle, a tomboy who knows jack shit about martial arts but still uses them anyway, a punk that may or may not be a huge softie on the inside, an old lady in mourning, the sibling of a murder victim, a detective whose competences probably rival that of Dick Gumshoe from Ace Attorney, to - and hear me out here - absolute perfection in the shape of a human being, capable in many ways, keeping up a demeanor so serious that once she opens up, she can't help but make it obvious she is socially awkward as all hell, albeit in a really cute way, and the dynamic between her and the player character is arguably the most rewarding one in the whole second trilogy of Persona games.

And don't even get me started on the soundtrack - every single tune in this game is a guaranteed earworm that will get stuck in your head all year long, from Signs of Love and Your Affection, through The Specialist, Heaven and Snowflakes, all the way to Long Way, Never More (a.k.a. - the one song that will ensure you left your heart in Inaba when you hear it) and even some returning Persona 3 tunes! It's something you have to hear for yourself to fully comprehend just how perfect it is.

I am excited to see what the upcoming Revival remake does to modernize the game, but regardless of what it does, Inaba will always feel like that home away from home worth going back to. It is quite easily a once in a generation masterpiece that everyone should at least give a try.

Persona 4 Golden is an outstanding JRPG that blends small‚Äëtown mystery, heartfelt character arcs, and stylish turn‚Äëbased combat into a cohesive, addictive loop that‚Äôs as compelling today as it was at release.
The PC/modern port elevates the experience with unlocked frame rates, higher resolutions, and fully remappable controls, making this the definitive way to play without altering the game‚Äôs soul.
Writing and social links shine with warmth and humor, supported by a killer soundtrack and dungeons that reward planning and exploiting weaknesses, keeping battles brisk and satisfying.
Even with a few dated beats and some filler in Golden‚Äôs added events, the overall journey remains top‚Äëtier‚Äîan easy recommendation for newcomers and veterans alike.

Persona 4 Golden was my first ever Persona game (that I beat), and I can confidently say it blew me away. I didn‚Äôt know what to expect going in, but it quickly became one of my top five PS2-era games of all time (I know its a PS Vita remaster). The mix of everyday school life, heartfelt friendships, and a gripping murder mystery kept me completely hooked from start to finish.

The cast is phenomenal ‚Äî every member of the Investigation Team feels real and memorable. Yu Narukami easily became one of my favorite protagonists ever, standing proudly alongside legends like Solid Snake and Kazuma Kiryu. He might be the ‚Äúsilent‚Äù type, but his presence and charisma make him unforgettable.

And I have to mention Naoto Shirogane ‚Äî my favorite character to romance in any game, [i]period[/i]. Her story, personality, and character growth hit all the right notes. Every moment with her felt genuine and meaningful, and she quickly became the heart of my playthrough.

The music deserves its own praise ‚Äî ‚ÄúReach Out to the Truth,‚Äù ‚ÄúHeaven,‚Äù and so many others have been stuck in my head ever since. Combine that with the emotional storytelling, fun combat, and charming small-town atmosphere, and you‚Äôve got something truly special.

Though by this point it is outclassed visually by both its successor P5 as well as the remake of its predecessor, P3 Reload, Persona 4 Golden is every bit as engaging as the other entries in the franchise. Its gameplay loop is familiar and satisfying, the combat is easy to grasp without being too rudimentary, and the setting is charming despite its relative lack of size or variety. The characters, as always with persona, shine (not Teddie but he's an outlier), and the group dynamics of the Investigation Team are every bit as interesting and fun as S.E.E.S or the Phantom Thieves. If you've played Persona 3 or 5 and you liked them, I'm sure you'll enjoy this one too.

If you began your acquaintance with the franchise from ‚ÄúPersona 3 Reload‚Äù as I did, you would likely abandon the game in the early beginning due to its poor appearance. But if you manage to overcome the first negative impression - you will find another jewel here. I promise you will not regret this!

The game has a very interesting story. We are going to solve a murder case in mystic settings. And we are not mere witnesses to a detective story. The case will not solve itself automatically - we have to do your own deductions to reach the actual final. The wrong decision may lead to accusing innocents and allowing the real culprit to escape.

There are many twists and quite an unexpected finale. However, the ‚Äúaftermath‚Äù in the very end spoils the impression, where the ‚Äúdetective story‚Äù slowly transforms into an ‚Äúexistential crisis‚Äù.

Alas not everything about the telling and quests is good.

The dialogues are quite twisted: it is hard to tell which exact choice means what or lead to what outcome. I have to replay several quests just because I misinterpreted the particular dialogue option. It‚Äôs not like every conversion has been implemented wrong, but it happens way too often.

The side quests are often twisted and require quite unobvious conditions to progress. In many cases it is hard to tell where we need to go and what we need to do. For example: there is a quest about a person who is afraid of cats. Talking to him has no effect. There are 2 cats in the vicinity, but interacting with them has no effect. The actual solution is yet another cat, which appears in the different part of town at the different time. What a?..

Yet another annoying activity is searching for clues on rescue missions, where it is unclear with whom we can talk, some key characters appear only on certain days of week, while ‚Äúclock is ticking‚Äù.

There are also some inconsistencies in the overall lore and telling. For example: at the beginning we have our weapons confiscated by police on the spot, but just the next day we purchase tons of them in the local shop without any notice.

The battle is turn based. We have to combine physical attacks with elemental magic. Some foes are weak to fire, but resistant to ice and so on. The key to the victory is in finding particular enemy weakness. 

Overall the combat is quite challenging and interesting. However, some things are unbalanced. Dark and Light have only ‚Äúinstant kill‚Äù spells. We encounter enemies, which can be knocked down with a physical attack and resistant to all elemental damage, but at the same time landing an elemental attack reduces more of their hit points, than physical one. Due to such things some battles appear really weird.

The power we use in combat - ‚ÄúPersona‚Äù - takes its origin in wielder‚Äôs mind and social links. Thus it is crucial to build a relationship with different characters and socialize. Also the main quest outcome is affected by our progress on this front.

The graphics are quite poor. It depicts the characters with a tiny body and oversized head. The main problem is not the lack of details or poor polygons, but the fact it creates a twisted unnatural image. This really spoils some scenes, like ‚Äúbeauty contest‚Äù, and quests, like when we meet a girl, which is later described as ‚Äúvoluptuous‚Äù, making a surprise since visually she looks like any other. The battle animations appear like some sort of parody played by dolls. And purchasing custom outfits for the characters sounds like a joke.

The ‚Äúvisual novel‚Äù dialogue presentation with detailed character portraits and some fully animated cartoon-cutscenes are quite a contrast to the main graphics, making it feel even worse.

In comparison to ‚ÄúPersona 3 Reload‚Äù the visuals are a big disappointment, but this is not a fair comparison, since this one is a backported original game, while ‚Äú3 Reload‚Äù is a remaster.

Still this is not a kind of game which is played for the graphics.

A lot of efforts have been put into music. Pop style songs with hooking voicing make the game feel bright and lively. There are also quite memorable moments of the concert we participate in.
Only a few dialogues are voiced. But even those which are represented as text usually contain some pronounced exclamations (like ‚Äúyes‚Äù, ‚Äúno‚Äù, ‚Äúsad‚Äù and so on), which illustrates the overall character emotion. So they still appear quite lively.

Total Rating 6-7/10.

P4 is a game with quite a few flaws in my opinion. It was difficult coming to P5's predecessor after experiencing a much more in-depth combat system. That being said, P4's graphics are extremely charming and nostalgic, the music is amazing (as with every Persona game), the characters are lovable (and annoying at times‚ÄîI'm looking at you Teddie), the final battle was hype-inducing, and it is difficult to say goodbye at the end when you're finally finished. Simply put, this is arguably the best game in the series. That isn't to say it's my pick for the best (that would be Persona 5) but this has every right to be there with it. And it could very well be at the top of the list for everyone else. I'm just partial to P5. This game has a fantastic cast, an interesting story, and a great soundtrack. It plays perfectly on Steam Deck, which is the best place to play a game like this. You can pop in for 30 minutes to an hour sitting on your couch, or laying in bed, put it to sleep and (battery willing) jump back in when you have more time.

Having played countless JRPGs over multiple decades... The best compliment I can give to any game in the genre is this- Despite my 80+ hours, it never felt like a slog. There wasn't a point where I felt it was hanging around past it's welcome. I didn't think about what game I was going to play next, I wasn't lamenting the grind or wanting things to hurry up. I just enjoyed P4G from start to finish. It might be prudent to wait for the remake that was announced, but if you can grab this on a solid sale, I still feel like it's worthwhile.

As someone who largely avoided JRPG's over the years, I had no background whatsoever on the Persona series when it was released on PC (and XBox consoles) a few years ago.  My teenage daughter at the time was very interested in the series and quickly started playing Persona 5 when it released, and encourage me to give it a try.  Not wanting to overlap, opted for her to play P5, and I would try out Persona 4 at the same time.

I am very glad I listened to her.

The Persona franchise has become a favorite of mine, and by now I have completed playthru's of P4. P5, and P3 Reload many times each.  However, P4G is my hands down favorite.  It has earned its place on my shortlist of all time favorite games, and has become one of those "comfort" titles; like the book or TV show that you have experienced many times before but keep going back to when you need something to cheer you up.  

Is it dated in terms of graphics?  Yes.  Very much so, but who cares?  In RPG's, story is king.

Are some of the characters a touch annoying at times?  Yes, but so are some of my relatives at holiday dinners; I still love them nonetheless.

In the end it's a good game that if you let it, will engross you for many hours at a respectable asking price.  It's a good example of when games were made to be enjoyed rather than cash grabs.

Genuinely such a good game, while it may be a bit old and  kinda outdated in some ways such as graphics, gameplay mechanics and some writing choices its still such a good game that I really enjoyed. It is the 3rd mainline Persona game I've played after P5R and P3R and yet the story and characters hold just as much compared to the first two. 

I've grown to love and care for the characters so much and I was looking forward to figuring out what the story was. Each character's struggles and flaws feel real and realistic which is exaggerated by good voice acting.

The small town rural setting is also genuinely so cool and makes the game feel more cozy and laidback, not to mention I've grown to like the artstyle of the town despite the outdated graphics.  seeing the same familiar faces all the time is kinda cool too. 
The music is an absolute banger too, maybe due to recency bias but in some ways its better than P3 and P5.  

I would highly recommend playing this if you have any interest in Persona, you can play this as your first game or your 3rd like me. I am also genuinely looking forward to the remake and I am curious to see how they improve upon an already really good game.
